physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top. The pages are rough on the edges as if torn out of a notebook. The third page also has, typed, H.M. in the top left corner, and the date (10/4/15) in the top right corner, as well as a -2- in the middle. There are also two black dots on each page that look like they could be from a hole punch.

div.p: Your letter of October 1st must have crossed with mine saying that I was withdrawing from the Levenson Prize. I do not want to withdraw a bit, but I know there is no hope of your giving me the prize; and I think it would be very foolish for me to get it, only I confess I should like the prestige sometime. I do not see quite how that can become got if I keep withdrawing. However, I do withdraw, of course; and, as I said in my last letter, I should be very glad if you would give me an honorable mention for something if you feel like doing so.

As to your suggestion that I review the book on Maurice Maeterlinck, I am afraid I must refuse since you want it for the December number. I have had to work so fearfully hard over this "e;Six French Poets"e; of mine, and the translations of the poems cited in the text have kept me at it so continuously all summer, that I have not been able to do as much creative work as I should like. I have a lot of ideas all piled up in my head which only lack
the time for me to give expression to, and I think I must give them a chance. I have still another two or three weeks' work on the "e;French Poets,"e; finishing up the proof reading; and after that I mean to take a month’s complete vacation and go off somewhere for a little rest. I have been almost steadily on the job since I returned from Europe a year ago, so I am afraid I could not promise to do your book before December; and as you want it at once, I rather think I had better refuse outright. I am awfully sorry that I should fail you at this juncture and, if you care to put it off and punish it in one of the early Spring numbers, I could probably do it for you; but I doubt whether you would find it that convenient.

You have been awfully good to Fletcher. He has written me of all you have done for him. Do not reproach yourself for anything left undone, for I am sure there has been nothing. His lack of savoir faire often leads him into brusqueries which make him seem less contented that he really is; and I know that he is really very grateful for your kindness.

p.add: My work on "e;ix French Poets"e; has delayed
p.pb: my article on your magazine; but you may be sure that I shall write it as soon as I can after my vacation and try to force it on “The New Republic.”
